labels_to_summaries.C0:
• Pittsburgh Water announced it is pausing four flood mitigation projects citywide due to funding shortfalls, including the Four Mile Run project that has been in development for six years

• The paused projects are Four Mile Run, Stewart Avenue, MLK Field, and South Side Park - with Four Mile Run being the most critical due to severe flooding that fills the neighborhood with sewage when heavy rains occur

• Pittsburgh Water has spent $8.7 million on the Four Mile Run project design, which is now 90% complete, but needs an additional $30 million for construction

• The project lost $10 million in funding from Alcasan when green infrastructure elements (stream daylighting) were removed due to permitting challenges with the state and CSX railroad

• Pittsburgh Water's $1.2 billion capital improvement plan over five years prioritizes mandated projects like the Water Reliability Plan (30% of funding) and lead service line replacement over stormwater projects

• Recent improvements to the M-29 outfall may have helped reduce flooding, but Pittsburgh Water is conducting hydraulic modeling to confirm the impact since no major storms have occurred since 2021

• Army Corps of Engineers representatives outlined potential federal funding programs that could provide 75% reimbursement for flood mitigation work if Pittsburgh Water applies

• Council Member Warwick expressed frustration that residents who fought against the Mon Oakland Connector road project now see their flood project canceled, calling it a crisis of faith in government

• Pittsburgh Water committed to completing analysis of recent improvements and exploring grant funding options before holding a community meeting in Four Mile Run
labels_to_summaries.G0:
- Pittsburgh Water (PWSA) announced it is putting four major flood mitigation projects on hold to prioritize other critical repairs.
- The agency is shifting funds to a **$470 million**, court-ordered “Water Reliability Plan” to upgrade drinking water infrastructure. This is part of a larger, nearly **$1.2 billion** five-year capital plan that also prioritizes replacing lead service lines.
- The four projects being paused are:
    - Four Mile Run
    - Stewart Avenue
    - MLK Field
    - South Side Park
- The Four Mile Run project, which addresses severe sewage flooding, is now 90% designed but lacks the estimated **$30 million** needed for construction.
- PWSA has already spent **$8.7 million** on the Four Mile Run project's design and early phases.
- A key setback for the project was the loss of **$10 million** in funding from the Allegheny County Sanitary Authority (Alcosan). The funding was withdrawn after green infrastructure elements were removed from the plan due to technical issues, meaning the project no longer met Alcosan’s requirements.
- PWSA is now studying whether other recent sewer work in the Four Mile Run area has already helped reduce flooding.
- The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers stated that PWSA could apply for federal programs that may cover up to 75% of project costs.
labels_to_summaries.O0:
- Pittsburgh Water has paused four major flood mitigation projects, including the Four Mile Run project, primarily due to funding challenges and increased construction costs.
- The Four Mile Run project is at 90% design but lost $10 million in funding after green infrastructure elements were removed, reducing its combined sewer overflow (CSO) reduction benefits below the funding threshold.
- Total project costs are estimated at $40 million, with about $8.7 million already spent on planning and design; construction alone is expected to cost around $30 million.
- Funding priorities have shifted toward mandated projects like the $470 million Water Reliability Plan, which addresses critical drinking water infrastructure and is court-ordered.
- Technical and permitting issues, including disagreements over stream lining and railroad right-of-way constraints, also complicated the Four Mile Run project.
- Pittsburgh Water continues to maintain existing infrastructure and respond to flooding complaints despite the project pause.
- The Army Corps of Engineers highlighted potential federal funding programs that could support future stormwater projects if Pittsburgh Water pursues partnerships.
- Councilmembers expressed concern over the impact on residents, especially in Four Mile Run, where flooding and sewage backups remain serious problems.
- Pittsburgh Water plans to complete design work and conduct hydraulic evaluations to assess recent improvements, such as the M-29 outfall reconstruction.
- Community engagement and transparent communication are planned before any future public meetings on the project’s status and next steps.
labels_to_summaries.C1:
• Council introduced a resolution allowing Team Pittsburgh Ball Hockey to live-stream dek hockey games at Marmaduke Park's rink at no cost to the city

• The agreement would involve LiveBarn, a sports streaming network that broadcasts amateur and youth sports using their equipment and software

• The dek hockey rink is located at Marmaduke Park on 3915 Oswald Street

• Council waived normal rules to fast-track the resolution to tomorrow's committee meeting

• The Mayor and Director of Public Works would be authorized to sign agreements with LiveBarn and/or Team Pittsburgh for the streaming service

• Any agreements must be approved by the City Solicitor for proper legal form
labels_to_summaries.G1:
- City Council introduced legislation that would allow Team Pittsburgh Ball Hockey to live-stream games from the dek hockey rink in Marmaduke Park.
- The streaming would be done through a partnership with LiveBarn, a company that specializes in broadcasting youth and amateur sports.
- Under the proposed agreement, the streaming service would be provided at no cost to the City.
- Council fast-tracked the bill so it could be reviewed by the Committee on Innovation, Performance, Asset Management, and Technology the following day.
- If approved, the legislation authorizes the Mayor and the Director of Public Works to enter into a formal agreement for the service.
labels_to_summaries.O1:
- The City Council authorized the Mayor and the Director of Public Works to enter into agreements with LiveBarn and Team Pittsburgh Ball Hockey.  
- These agreements will allow Team Pittsburgh to live-stream dek hockey games at the Dek Hockey Rink in Marmaduke Park.  
- The live-streaming service will be provided at no cost to the City.  
- The resolution was introduced by Councilwoman Deborah L. Gross and was waived under Rule 8 to appear on the Standing Committee agenda promptly.  
- The agreements must be approved by the City Solicitor to ensure proper legal form.
labels_to_summaries.C2:
• Council is considering a resolution to approve a sewage plan revision for a development at 7415 Hermitage Street in the 13th Ward

• The developer, WNT Daniels Real Estate LLC, wants to connect to the city's sewer system using four sewer tap-ins for their land development project

• The revision covers multiple property lots: 174-G-390, 174-G-392, 174-G-194, and 174-G-396

• Several agencies have already reviewed and approved the plan:
  - Pittsburgh Water Sewer Authority
  - Allegheny County Sanitary Authority  
  - City Planning Department
  - Allegheny County Health Department

• The city finds the project meets zoning rules, municipal laws, and pollution control standards

• The plan revision will cost the city nothing - all expenses are covered by the developer

• The resolution was introduced by Councilman Khari Mosley and referred to the Committee on Intergovernmental and Educational Affairs
labels_to_summaries.G2:
- A resolution was introduced to update the city’s Official Sewage Facilities Plan for a new development at 7415 Hermitage Street.
- The developer, WNT Daniels Real Estate LLC, is planning a project that will cover four land parcels.
- The development will require four new sewer connections, or "tap-ins," to the public sewage system.
- State law requires the city to officially approve such updates, which have already been reviewed by the Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority and the Allegheny County Health Department.
- The change to the city's plan will be made at no cost to the City of Pittsburgh.
labels_to_summaries.O2:
- The City Council adopted a resolution revising the Official Sewage Facilities Plan for the property at 7415 Hermitage Street, Pittsburgh, PA 15208.  
- The revision allows for four new sewer tap-ins to serve the proposed land development by WNT Daniels Real Estate LLC.  
- The plan revision was reviewed and approved by the Pittsburgh Water Sewer Authority, Allegheny County Sanitary Authority, City Planning Department, and Allegheny County Health Department.  
- The project meets all zoning, subdivision, and environmental regulations, ensuring compliance with pollution control and water quality management standards.  
- The adoption of this plan revision comes at no cost to the City of Pittsburgh.  
- This action updates the City’s Official Sewage Facilities Plan to support the new development while protecting public health and the environment.

labels_to_summaries.C4:

- A resolution was introduced to authorize a payment of up to $6,158.30 to the New Pittsburgh Courier.

- The bill was presented by Councilwoman Erika Strassburger.
- The resolution has been sent to the Committee on Finance and Law for review before a final vote by the full council.
labels_to_summaries.O4:
- The City Council approved a resolution to pay the New Pittsburgh Courier, operating as Real Times, Inc., for legal advertisements related to the City of Pittsburgh’s Quiet Title actions.  
- The payment amount authorized is up to $6,158.30 for ads published on February 5, 2025.

labels_to_summaries.C5:
• Council referred a resolution to the Finance and Law Committee to authorize contracts with five vendors for special events services

• The city would enter into 11 separate agreements with these companies: Acrobatique Creative, Bounce Marketing & Events, Flyspace Productions, Elevation Management, and Platinum Street

• Each contract allows up to $750,000 per year for three years, providing on-call professional services to various city departments

• Individual work orders under these contracts cannot exceed $100,000 per project

• The agreements provide "readily available" services on an as-needed basis rather than guaranteed work

• Funding will be identified and approved by Council when specific work orders are issued

• The contracts were selected through an Invitation to Qualify process issued in February 2025
labels_to_summaries.G5:
- The City Council introduced a resolution to create 11 professional services agreements with five different companies for on-call special events services.
- The contracts would be for a three-year term and used by various city departments as needed.
- Each of the 11 agreements would have an annual spending cap of $750,000.
- No single project or work order under these agreements can cost more than $100,000.
- The five vendors selected are Acrobatique Creative, Bounce Marketing & Events, Flyspace Productions, Elevation Management, and Platinum Street.
- The legislation has been referred to the Committee on Finance and Law for further review.
labels_to_summaries.O5:
- City Council approved eleven (11) Open-End Professional Services Agreements with five vendors to provide on-call special events services for various City departments.  
- The vendors are Acrobatique Creative, Bounce Marketing & Events, Flyspace Productions, Elevation Management, and Platinum Street.  
- Each agreement is for a three-year term with a maximum annual cost of $750,000 per vendor.  
- Individual work orders under these agreements will not exceed $100,000 each.  
- Funding for services will be allocated as needed through the City’s Operating and Capital Budgets and require City Council approval if not previously appropriated.  
- These agreements ensure the City has readily available professional support for special events on an as-needed basis.
labels_to_summaries.C6:
• Council authorized city departments to record temporary construction easements on city-owned property for the Smithfield Street repair project

• The easements will allow necessary site access and construction staging for rehabilitation, reconstruction, and repair work on Smithfield Street

• The project uses federal and state funding and is overseen by the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT)

• The city will record a right-of-way plan with the Allegheny County Recorder of Deeds to document the temporary easements and commit to non-interference during construction

• The authorization comes at no cost to the city since the easements are on city-owned parcels

• The resolution was presented by Councilwoman Barbara Warwick and referred to the Committee on Public Works and Infrastructure
labels_to_summaries.G6:
- The City of Pittsburgh is taking a formal step to prepare for a major repair and reconstruction project on Smithfield Street.
- To allow for construction site access and staging areas, the project requires temporary legal access, known as construction easements.
- Because the project uses state and federal funding, it is overseen by the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT), which requires these easements to be formally recorded.
- The easements will be placed on property the city already owns, making this a formal, internal process to meet PennDOT's rules.
- City Council is considering a resolution that would authorize the Departments of Finance and Mobility and Infrastructure to officially record the easements with the county.
- According to the legislation, this action will be done at no cost to the city.
labels_to_summaries.O6:
- Councilwoman Barbara Warwick presented Resolution 2025-1750 to authorize the Directors of Finance and Mobility and Infrastructure to record temporary construction easements on certain City-owned parcels.  
- These easements are needed to support the rehabilitation, reconstruction, and repair project for Smithfield Street in Pittsburgh.  
- The project is overseen by PennDOT due to federal and state funding involvement.  
- The City has completed a right-of-way plan showing the necessary temporary easements for construction access and staging.  
- Recording these easements with the Allegheny County Recorder of Deeds will formalize the City’s commitment to non-interference during the project.  
- The resolution confirms that all actions will be taken at no cost to the City.
labels_to_summaries.M7:

  - A spud barge is a semi-permanent floating platform that can be assembled from multple sctions joined together
- The barge will be open to the public via the City-owned dock and will:
  - “celebrate Pittsburgh’s rivers through primarily free, accessible, and sustainable activities and events.”
- Riverlife is selecting a vendor for a concession stand.

labels_to_summaries.C7:
• Council referred a resolution to the Public Works and Infrastructure Committee that would allow Riverlife to connect their public programming barge to the city-owned Allegheny Landing Dock

• The barge would be located on the Allegheny River next to Allegheny Landing Park, between the Roberto Clemente and Andy Warhol bridges in the North Shore

• Riverlife plans to launch the sectional spud barge in 2025 with a 30-foot gangway connecting it to the city dock for public access during operating hours

• The agreement would cost the city nothing and is intended to "activate and celebrate Pittsburgh's rivers through primarily free, accessible and sustainable activities and events"

• The resolution authorizes the Mayor and directors of Public Works and Finance to enter into agreements with Riverlife for dock access

• Any final agreement must be approved by the City Solicitor
labels_to_summaries.G7:
- City Council is considering a proposal from the nonprofit Riverlife to connect a floating barge for public events to the city-owned Allegheny Landing Dock.
- The barge would host "primarily free, accessible and sustainable" public programs and events, with plans to launch in 2025.
- It would be located on the Allegheny River along the North Shore, between the Roberto Clemente (6th Street) and Andy Warhol (7th Street) bridges.
- A 30-foot gangway would provide public access from the dock to the barge.
- The proposed agreement would allow Riverlife to use the city dock at no cost to the City.
- The legislation (Bill 2025-1751) was introduced and sent to the Committee on Public Works and Infrastructure for further review before a final vote.
labels_to_summaries.O7:
- City Council approved a resolution allowing the Mayor and Directors of Public Works and Finance to enter into agreements with Riverlife.  
- The agreements permit Riverlife to use the Allegheny Landing Dock to provide public access to their Riverlife Barge at no cost to the city.  
- The Barge will be located on the Allegheny River next to Allegheny Landing Park in 2025.  
- Access will be via a 30-foot gangway connecting the Barge to the City-owned Dock.  
- Riverlife’s programming on the Barge aims to offer free, accessible, and sustainable public events celebrating Pittsburgh’s rivers.  
- The agreements will be reviewed and approved by the City Solicitor to ensure proper legal form.
labels_to_summaries.M8:
- Bill would exempt intentional plantings of native Pennsylvania vegetation from code violations to enhance biodiversity and protect the City’s environment.
- The exemption covers:
  - Native Gardens: A planned garden using plants that naturally grow in Pennsylvania and are suited to its climate and soil.
  - Pollinator Gardens: A garden designed to attract and support pollinators like bees, butterflies, and hummingbirds by offering food, water, and shelter.
  - Rain Gardens: A shallow, landscaped area with native plants that captures and filters rainwater runoff.
- Current City Code prohibits these landscapes and all plant and weed growth over 10 inches on residential properties.
- Residents must register their gardens with the City before planting.
- Violations incur a $15-per-day fine.
- Bill will be discussed at next week’s Standing Committee meeting.
labels_to_summaries.C8:
• Council introduced an ordinance allowing Pittsburgh residents to plant and maintain native gardens and natural landscapes on their property

• The legislation creates a new section in the city code specifically for "managed natural landscapes," which include rain gardens, native gardens, and pollinator gardens using plants native to Pennsylvania

• Property owners must register their natural landscapes with the city and pay a fee to cover program costs

• Gardens must have clearly defined borders using mowed grass, fencing up to 4 feet high, or natural materials

• Prohibited plants include invasive species identified by Pennsylvania agencies and any plants that create safety hazards or violate existing property maintenance rules

• Registration requires either a detailed maintenance plan with plant species and square footage, or certification from organizations like the Audubon Society

• The city can require removal of landscapes that harbor pests or violate the rules after issuing a notice

• The ordinance was sponsored by Council Member Warwick and referred to the Land Use and Economic Development Committee

• If approved, the new rules would take effect January 1, 2026
labels_to_summaries.G8:
- A new ordinance has been proposed that would allow Pittsburgh residents to create "managed natural landscapes," such as native plant gardens, pollinator gardens, and rain gardens, on their properties.
- The goal of the proposed law is to increase local biodiversity and support the environment by encouraging the use of plants native to Pennsylvania.
- To qualify, gardens must be planned, intentional, and well-maintained, not just overgrown turfgrass lawns.
- Residents would be required to register their gardens with the city, providing either a maintenance plan and plant list or a certification from an approved program like the Audubon Society or Penn State Master Gardeners.
- Gardens must have a clearly defined border and cannot contain any plant species identified as invasive or noxious by the state.
- The ordinance, sponsored by Councilmember Warwick, was introduced and sent to a committee for review. If passed, it would take effect on January 1, 2026.
labels_to_summaries.O8:
- Pittsburgh City Council introduced Ordinance 2025-1770 to allow residents to plant and maintain managed natural landscapes on private property.
- The ordinance adds Section 609.08 to the City Code, defining managed natural landscapes as planned plantings of native Pennsylvania plants, including rain gardens, native gardens, and pollinator gardens.
- Managed natural landscapes must have clearly defined borders and cannot include invasive or noxious plants, weeds, or unmanaged turfgrass overgrowth.
- Property owners or tenants must register their managed natural landscapes with the City, providing a maintenance plan, plant species list, and area size, or certification from recognized organizations.
- The City may charge a registration fee and enforce compliance, including requiring removal if the landscape harbors pests or violates maintenance codes.
- The ordinance aims to increase biodiversity and environmental benefits while balancing public safety and property maintenance.
- The new rules will take effect on January 1, 2026.
labels_to_summaries.M9:

labels_to_summaries.C15:
• Council unanimously passed an ordinance clarifying where residential parking permit signs can be posted and enforced throughout the city.

• Signs can only be posted on streets located in residential zoning districts or specific zones including H, UPR-B, RIV-RM, GPR, OPR-A, or RP districts.

• In non-residential areas, signs can only be posted in Hybrid RPP areas or at the discretion of the Parking Permit Officer.

• Areas with dynamic hours cannot be enforced between 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on any day, and have no enforcement on Sundays from 2:00 a.m. to 11:59 p.m.

• Evening enforcement is only allowed in designated Parking Enhancement Districts.

• The Department of Mobility and Infrastructure is responsible for posting signs that clearly show parking restrictions and rates where applicable.

• The ordinance was sponsored by Council Member Charland and passed with all nine council members voting yes.
labels_to_summaries.G15:

- The law specifies which streets are eligible for permit parking enforcement, including any block located in a Residential Zoning District and several other specific zones (H, UPR-B, RIV-RM, GPR, OPR-A, or RP).
- For permit areas with "dynamic hours," the ordinance sets specific times when rules will **not** be enforced:
  - Daily between 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m.
  - All day on Sundays.
- Evening permit enforcement is now limited only to designated Parking Enhancement Districts.

- Signs and enforcement are limited to blockfaces within specific residential zoning districts or designated hybrid areas, with enforcement discretion given to the Parking Permit Officer.  
- Residential permit areas with dynamic hours will not be enforced between 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. daily, and no enforcement will occur on Sundays in these areas.

labels_to_summaries.C19:
• Pittsburgh City Council unanimously approved a deal allowing ALCOSAN to build underground tunnels through nine city-owned properties for $8,200.

• The tunnels will be built about 150 feet below ground as part of ALCOSAN's larger regional tunnel system along the Ohio, Allegheny, and Monongahela Rivers.

• This tunnel project is required under a 2008 federal consent decree to reduce combined sewer overflows by separating stormwater from the sanitary sewer system.

• The city will grant permanent underground easements to ALCOSAN for the tunnel construction on the nine parcels.

• The vote was 9-0 with no discussion from council members before the final vote.

• The mayor, finance director, and public works director are now authorized to sign the agreements with ALCOSAN.
labels_to_summaries.G19:
*   The Pittsburgh City Council voted unanimously to grant the Allegheny County Sanitary Authority (ALCOSAN) permanent underground access to nine city-owned properties.
*   In exchange for the access, ALCOSAN will pay the city a one-time fee of $8,200.
*   The access, known as an easement, will allow ALCOSAN to build tunnels about 150 feet below the surface.
*   These tunnels are part of a major, ongoing project to improve the regional sewer system and reduce overflows into the rivers.
*   The project is required by a 2008 Consent Decree between ALCOSAN and federal and state environmental agencies.
*   Council passed the resolution with a 9-0 vote, authorizing the mayor and other officials to finalize the agreement.
labels_to_summaries.O19:
- City Council unanimously approved a resolution allowing the Mayor, Director of Finance, and Director of Public Works to enter into agreements with the Allegheny County Sanitary Authority (ALCOSAN).  
- The agreements grant ALCOSAN permanent subterranean easements for tunnels under nine City-owned properties, identified by specific Allegheny County Parcel IDs.  
- The easements support ALCOSAN’s Tunnel Project, aimed at improving the regional sewer system by constructing tunnels about 150 feet underground to reduce combined sewer overflows.  
- The City will receive $8,200 in payment for these easements.  
- The resolution passed with a 9-0 vote, with no opposition or abstentions.
labels_to_summaries.C20:
• Council approved a special meeting focused on police, EMS, and fire department equipment after an ambulance broke down while responding to a cardiac arrest call

• The breakdown forced dispatchers to send a second ambulance to the emergency, highlighting serious equipment problems

• Councilman Coghill, who chairs public safety, requested the meeting and expressed concern about the overall condition of emergency vehicle fleets

• This follows a similar fleet review Coghill called for two years ago, but he says conditions haven't improved much due to lack of funding

• Council President Wilson supported the urgent meeting, calling ambulance breakdowns during emergencies "seriously wrong" and blaming lack of investment in basic equipment

• The meeting will focus only on life-saving departments (police, EMS, fire) and exclude other city departments like public works

• Council plans to schedule the meeting as soon as possible, potentially next week, given the emergency nature of the situation

• Leaders emphasized the need to properly equip emergency responders who risk their lives to help the public
labels_to_summaries.G20:
- City Council voted to schedule a special hearing to discuss the condition of vehicles used by the police, fire, and EMS departments.
- The decision came after an incident where an ambulance broke down while responding to a cardiac arrest, forcing a second ambulance to be dispatched.
- Councilman Coghill, who requested the hearing, noted he had raised concerns about the entire city fleet two years ago but the situation has not improved due to a lack of funding.
- The council president called the issue an "emergency" caused by a "lack of investments" and said it's time to "stop patching things up and let's start fixing them right."
- The motion to hold the future hearing passed with unanimous support.
labels_to_summaries.O20:
- Councilman Coghill called for a special post-agenda meeting focused on the condition of the EMS, fire, and police vehicle fleets due to recent ambulance breakdowns during emergency calls.  
- The last full fleet review was two years ago, and little progress has been made in funding or repairs since then.  
- Coghill emphasized the urgency of addressing life-saving equipment failures and plans to hear directly from department directors about the current state of their fleets.  
- Council President and other members supported scheduling the meeting as soon as possible, ideally next week, citing public safety risks and the need for transparent discussion.  
- The council agreed unanimously to hold this focused session to explore solutions and necessary investments to ensure reliable emergency response vehicles.
labels_to_summaries.M21:
- The amendment to the residential zoning ordinance reduces minimum lot sizes for all density levels and removes the minimum unit-size requirement for apartments and condos.
  - All other zoning rules remain unchanged.
- While Council generally supported the text, some members raised concerns about:
  - Timing the vote right after this week’s severe storm
  - Whether zoning changes should be made individually or all at once
  - If minimum lot sizes were the most critical amendment among many under consideration
- The bill received an affirmative recommendation, passing 5–1 with two abstentions. Councilperson Gross voted against with Councilpersons Lavelle and Warwick abstaining. Councilperson Mosley was absent.
- Current Min Lot Size:
  - Very Low Density (VL): 8,000 sq ft
  - Low Density (L): 5,000 sq ft
  - Moderate Density (M): 3,200 sq ft
  - High Density (H): 1,800 sq ft
  - Very High Density (VH): 1,200 sq ft
- Proposed Min Lot Size:
  - Very Low Density (VL): 6,000 sq ft
  - Low Density (L): 3,000 sq ft
  - Moderate Density (M): 2,400 sq ft
  - High Density (H): 1,200 sq ft
  - Very High Density (VH): None
labels_to_summaries.C21:
• Pittsburgh City Council held a public hearing on Bill 1579, which would reduce minimum lot size requirements across all residential zoning districts in the city

• **Current vs. proposed minimum lot sizes:**
  - Very low density: 8,000 to 6,000 square feet
  - Low density: 5,000 to 3,000 square feet  
  - Moderate density: 3,200 to 2,400 square feet
  - High density: 1,800 to 1,200 square feet
  - Very high density: 1,200 square feet to no minimum

• **The bill would eliminate minimum lot size per unit requirements** that currently restrict how many housing units can be built on a property

• City planning staff showed that **18% to over 50% of existing lots** in various residential districts don't meet current minimum size requirements, making many homes technically non-conforming

• **Supporters argued** the changes would make housing more affordable, allow rebuilding of homes that match neighborhood character, and reduce barriers for developers at the zoning board

• **Critics raised concerns** about increased density in already crowded areas, potential for gentrification, and preference for addressing short-term rentals instead

• The bill was originally part of a larger zoning package that included inclusionary zoning and parking reforms, but Council Member Wilson separated it for individual consideration

• **Many speakers urged Council to consider the full zoning package together** rather than piecemeal, arguing the reforms work better as a comprehensive approach

• The bill has support from Council Members Wilson (sponsor), Warwick, and Charland (co-sponsors)
labels_to_summaries.G21:
- The City Council held a public hearing for Bill 1579, which proposes reducing the minimum lot size required to build a home and removing the minimum lot size required per housing unit.

- The bill, sponsored by Councilmembers Wilson, Warwick, and Charland, is based on a recommendation from the 2022 Housing Needs Assessment to help address the city's housing shortage and affordability challenges.

- City Planning staff explained that a large number of existing city lots are smaller than current rules allow, making it difficult to build new homes or even rebuild existing ones. The proposed changes include:
    - **Very-Low Density:** 8,000 sq. ft. reduced to 6,000 sq. ft.
    - **Low-Density:** 5,000 sq. ft. reduced to 3,000 sq. ft.
    - **Moderate-Density:** 3,200 sq. ft. reduced to 2,400 sq. ft.
    - **High-Density:** 1,800 sq. ft. reduced to 1,200 sq. ft.
    - **Very-High Density:** 1,200 sq. ft. minimum requirement removed entirely.

- Many members of the public spoke in favor of the bill, stating that current rules make much of the city's historic housing illegal to rebuild. They argued the changes would allow for more housing to be built on vacant lots, increase supply, and "re-legalize" homes that fit neighborhood character.

- A second group supported the idea but opposed passing it separately from a larger package of zoning reforms. They argued that this "piecemeal" approach would pass developer-friendly changes while leaving behind more critical affordability measures like inclusionary zoning.

- A third group of speakers opposed the bill entirely, arguing it would lead to overcrowding, harm neighborhood quality of life, and benefit "predatory landlords" without creating truly affordable housing.
labels_to_summaries.O21:
- The City Council held a public hearing on Bill 1579, which aims to reduce minimum lot size requirements across Pittsburgh’s residential zoning districts to encourage more housing development and affordability.  
- The bill lowers minimum lot sizes as follows:  
  - Very Low-Density: from 8,000 to 6,000 sq. ft.  
  - Low-Density: from 5,000 to 3,000 sq. ft.  
  - Moderate Density: from 3,200 to 2,400 sq. ft.  
  - High Density: from 1,800 to 1,200 sq. ft.  
  - Very High Density: removes minimum lot size entirely.  
- It also eliminates minimum lot size per unit requirements, which currently restrict multi-unit housing development, especially duplexes and triplexes.  
- The reform addresses a major barrier where many existing lots (up to over 50% in some districts) do not meet current minimum lot sizes, making many homes technically illegal and new development difficult without variances.  
- Supporters emphasized that the bill would legalize many existing homes, allow more modest and affordable housing types, increase housing supply, and promote walkability and transit use.  
- The bill is based on recommendations from the 2022 Housing Needs Assessment and has been vetted through extensive public engagement and planning commission approval without conditions.  
- Several speakers urged passing this bill quickly to address Pittsburgh’s housing crisis, while also calling for the full comprehensive zoning package—including inclusionary zoning and parking reforms—to be adopted together for maximum impact.  
- Some opponents expressed concerns about potential neighborhood crowding, gentrification, and the piecemeal approach of separating this bill from the full zoning reform package.  
- Councilmembers sponsoring the bill highlighted the need to move forward with this “clean fix” now to unlock vacant lots, reduce red tape, and align zoning with the city’s historic built environment.  
- The hearing concluded with broad council support to advance the bill while acknowledging ongoing debates about the broader housing reform package.

labels_to_summaries.G22:
- Pittsburgh City Council is reviewing the proposed sale of a city-owned lot on Itin Street in the 23rd Ward.
- The property was acquired by the city in a 2020 tax sale.
- A company named East Side Property has offered to buy the lot for $3,755.
- The proposed plan is to use the land for green space and residential parking.
- Council members voted to delay a final decision on the sale for one week to allow for more discussion.
labels_to_summaries.O22:
- The City Council discussed Resolution 2025-1675, which proposes the sale of a property in the 23rd Ward, First Council District, acquired by the city at a tax sale in December 2020.  
- The property, located at 0 Itin Street, is designated for green space, parking, and residential use, with a purchase price set at $3,755.  
- The resolution authorizes the City Solicitor to petition the court for the sale, with all zoning and legal requirements to be observed.  
- During the meeting, Council members agreed to hold the resolution for one week for further consideration before moving forward.  
- The hold means no immediate sale will occur, and the matter will return for discussion by April 30, 2025.
labels_to_summaries.C23:
• Council Member Wilson sponsored a resolution to move $33,292 from city council district salaries to employee benefits to pay for tuition reimbursement for council staff

• The money transfer stays within the 2025 city operating budget - no new spending is involved

• Council voted to hold the resolution for six weeks in the Finance and Law Committee

• The committee must report back on the resolution by June 4, 2025

• The funds would come from regular salary and wage accounts and go into employee benefits accounts specifically for education costs
labels_to_summaries.G23:
- A resolution to transfer $33,292 to pay for City Council staff tuition reimbursement was put on hold for six weeks.
- The proposal, sponsored by Council Member Wilson, would move the funds within the council’s 2025 operating budget.
- The money would be transferred from the "Salaries and Wages" account to the "Employee Benefits" account.
- The legislation will be held in the Committee on Finance and Law for further review.
labels_to_summaries.O23:
- The City Council voted to hold a $33,292 budget transfer for six weeks.
- The transfer would move funds within the 2025 Operating Budget from City Council Districts Salaries & Wages to Employee Benefits.
- The purpose of the transfer is to cover tuition reimbursement expenses.
- The motion to hold the transfer was approved unanimously in the Committee on Finance and Law.
- The hold delays the transfer’s implementation until at least June 4, 2025.
labels_to_summaries.M24:
- Council authorized a $40,000 contract with Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy, LLP, a global immigration law firm.
- The authorization was discussed in an executive session closed to the public and was not presented in Standing Committee before approval.
- InformUp contacted both the Councilperson Lavelle's office and the law firm for additional information but received no response by publication time.
labels_to_summaries.C24:
• Council approved a $40,000 contract with the law firm Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy, LLP to provide immigration legal services

• The one-year professional services agreement will help the city handle immigration-related legal matters

• The contract was discussed in executive session on April 15, 2025, before coming to the full council for approval

• Council voted unanimously to give the contract an affirmative recommendation

• The agreement allows the Mayor and City Solicitor to formally enter into the contract with the law firm

• Funding will come from the city's budget account 11101.108000.53.53517.2025
labels_to_summaries.G24:
- The City Council approved a resolution authorizing a one-year contract for legal services related to immigration issues.
- The agreement is with the law firm Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy, LLP, for an amount not to exceed $40,000.
- The Mayor and the City Solicitor are now authorized to finalize the professional services agreement.
- Council members approved the measure with a unanimous vote and no public discussion during the meeting.
labels_to_summaries.O24:
- The City Council approved a resolution authorizing the Mayor and City Solicitor to enter into a one-year Professional Services Agreement with Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy, LLP.  
- The contract amount is capped at $40,000 for legal services related to immigration matters.  
- Funding for the agreement will come from account 11101.108000.53.53517.2025.  
- The agreement’s form must be approved by the City Solicitor before execution.  
- The resolution was unanimously affirmed during the meeting with no further discussion.
labels_to_summaries.C25:
• Council voted to hold an ordinance that would increase paid sick leave benefits for Pittsburgh workers for a public hearing scheduled for May 28, 2025.

• The proposed changes would affect all employees working in Pittsburgh:
  - Workers at companies with 15+ employees: earn 1 hour of paid sick time for every 30 hours worked, up to 72 hours per year maximum
  - Workers at companies with fewer than 15 employees: earn 1 hour of sick time for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year maximum

• Council President Lavelle sponsored the ordinance but was not present during the initial discussion due to technical difficulties.

• The legislation would take effect January 1, 2026 if approved after the public hearing.

• Key provisions include:
  - Sick time carries over to the next year unless employers provide the full amount upfront
  - Workers must wait 90 days after starting a job before using accrued sick time
  - Previously earned sick time is restored if workers are rehired within 6 months

• Employers with existing paid time off policies that meet these requirements would not need to provide additional sick time.
labels_to_summaries.G25:
- A proposal to increase the amount of paid sick time workers can earn in Pittsburgh is moving forward after a City Council vote.
- The ordinance, sponsored by Council President Lavelle, would make the following changes to the city’s Paid Sick Days Act:
    - For businesses with 15 or more employees, the maximum sick time an employee can accumulate would increase to 72 hours per year.
    - For businesses with fewer than 15 employees, the maximum would increase to 48 hours per year.
    - All employees would earn sick time at a rate of one hour for every 30 hours worked.
- Council members voted to schedule a public hearing to gather feedback on the proposed changes before taking a final vote.
- If the legislation is approved, the new rules would take effect on January 1, 2026.
labels_to_summaries.O25:
- Council held Bill 1736, which proposes changes to the Pittsburgh Paid Sick Days Act, for a public hearing rather than voting on it immediately.  
- The bill would increase the rate at which employees accrue paid sick leave and raise the maximum hours they can accumulate annually.  
- For employers with 15 or more employees, sick leave accrual is set at 1 hour per 30 hours worked, with a maximum of 72 hours per year.  
- For employers with fewer than 15 employees, the maximum accrual is 48 hours per year under the same accrual rate.  
- The ordinance would take effect on January 1, 2026.  
- Council President Lavelle requested the bill be held for public input before final approval.  
- The motion to hold the bill for a public hearing passed unanimously.
labels_to_summaries.C26:
• City Council approved an agreement allowing the University of Pittsburgh to pay for up to 15 additional trash pickups in Oakland during busy periods like student move-in, move-out, and holiday breaks.

• The university will cover all city costs for the extra collections, including labor, equipment, recycling, and landfill fees — at no cost to the city.

• Council amended the original proposal to change from a fixed $3,000 per pickup to actual costs incurred, providing flexibility as landfill and recycling costs fluctuate.

• The program addresses Oakland's periodic waste problems when university students generate significantly more trash than normal.

• Previous efforts by the university using private contractors created confusion and were less effective than expected.

• Past attempts to place dumpsters on streets during move-in periods failed due to abuse, with non-residents filling them before students could use them.

• Public Works Director Chris Hornstein said the biggest trash volumes occur when students move back in the fall, and the city will be ready for that period.

• The agreement allows the city's waste collection system to handle the increased volume more effectively than private contractors while ensuring the university pays the full cost.
labels_to_summaries.G26:
- The University of Pittsburgh will pay for the city to conduct up to 15 extra trash collections in the Oakland neighborhood.
- These supplemental pickups will happen as needed, with a focus on times when trash piles up, like during student move-in and move-out periods.
- The university will pay the city for its "actual costs incurred" for the extra work, covering labor, equipment, and disposal fees.
- This arrangement was created because past efforts by the university to hire a private company for the same job were considered confusing and not very effective.
- City officials noted that an earlier attempt to place large dumpsters on the street during move-out was unsuccessful because they were misused by people from outside the neighborhood.
labels_to_summaries.O26:
- The City Council approved an amended resolution allowing the Mayor and Public Works Director to enter into an agreement with the University of Pittsburgh for supplemental waste collection in the Oakland neighborhood at no cost to the city.  
- The University will fund up to 15 additional waste pickups annually, mainly during high-trash periods like student move-in and move-out.  
- The amendment changed the payment from a fixed $3,000 per event to covering actual costs incurred, allowing flexibility due to fluctuating recycling and landfill fees.  
- The University had previously tried managing waste pickups with a private vendor, but it was less effective and caused confusion.  
- Public Works will now handle the supplemental pickups, with costs reimbursed by the University to cover labor, equipment, and disposal fees.  
- Councilmembers expressed appreciation for the partnership and emphasized the importance of maintaining cleanliness in Oakland, while also noting ongoing waste challenges in other neighborhoods.  
- The agreement requires approval by the City Solicitor before finalization.
labels_to_summaries.C27:
• City Council approved an agreement allowing Almono, LP to build and maintain six new bus shelters in the Hazelwood neighborhood at no cost to the city

• The bus shelters will be located along Second Avenue and Blair Street

• Under the agreement, Almono, LP will design, construct, own, and maintain the shelters for a designated time period with possible extensions

• The Department of Mobility and Infrastructure has already approved the locations for the new bus shelters

• The resolution received an affirmative recommendation from council
labels_to_summaries.G27:
- City Council approved an agreement with the developer Almono, LP to build six new bus shelters in the Hazelwood neighborhood.
- The shelters will be located along Second Avenue and Blair Street.
- Under the agreement, Almono, LP will design, construct, own, and maintain the shelters.
- The project will be completed at no cost to the city.
- The resolution authorizes the Mayor and the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure to finalize the ownership and maintenance agreement with the developer.
labels_to_summaries.O27:
- City Council approved a resolution authorizing the Mayor and the Director of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure to enter into an agreement with Almono, LP.  
- The agreement covers the construction, ownership, and maintenance of six new bus shelters along Second Avenue and Blair Street in the Hazelwood neighborhood.  
- Almono, LP will design, build, own, and maintain the shelters at no cost to the City of Pittsburgh.  
- The Department of Mobility and Infrastructure has approved the locations for the shelters.  
- The agreement formalizes the terms for ownership and upkeep of the shelters for a set period, with possible extensions.  
- The motion to approve the resolution passed unanimously during the council meeting.
labels_to_summaries.C28:
• Council approved an agreement allowing Team Pittsburgh Ball Hockey to live-stream dek hockey games at Marmaduke Park through LiveBarn sports streaming network

• The agreement costs the city nothing and was given affirmative recommendation

• LiveBarn provides amateur and youth sports broadcasting equipment and software for the streaming

• Marmaduke Park is located at 3915 Oswald Street in Pittsburgh's Brighton Heights neighborhood

• Team Pittsburgh has a dek hockey tournament coming up this summer that will be available for live streaming

• The streaming will allow parents and others to watch games remotely when they can't attend in person

• Councilman Wilson praised Team Pittsburgh for making the area vibrant, operating a concession stand for the whole community, and bringing people to the neighborhood

• The Department of Public Works helped put the agreement together and maintains Marmaduke Park
labels_to_summaries.G28:
- City Council approved a resolution authorizing an agreement to live-stream dek hockey games from the rink at Marmaduke Park.
- The city will partner with Team Pittsburgh Ball Hockey and the streaming service LiveBarn to provide the broadcast.
- This service will be provided at no cost to the city.
- The live stream will allow parents, family, and fans to watch games remotely and is expected to be available for a tournament this summer.
labels_to_summaries.O28:
- City Council approved Resolution 2025-1746 authorizing the Mayor and the Director of Public Works to enter into agreements with LiveBarn and Team Pittsburgh Ball Hockey.  
- The agreements allow Team Pittsburgh to live-stream dek hockey games at the Dek Hockey Rink in Marmaduke Park at no cost to the City.  
- LiveBarn provides the streaming technology and software for amateur and youth sports broadcasts.  
- Councilman Wilson highlighted that the live streaming will let parents and others watch games remotely, especially during the upcoming summer tournament.  
- Marmaduke Park and the dek hockey program are important community hubs in Brighton Heights, with active local engagement including a concession stand.  
- The agreement was unanimously approved with thanks to the Department of Public Works and Team Pittsburgh for their efforts.
labels_to_summaries.C29:
• City Council approved transferring a city-owned property at 219 Reifert Street to the Pittsburgh Land Bank for $1 plus expenses

• The property is located in the 30th Ward, Council District 3, and is officially designated as Block 33-K, Lot 128

• The Pittsburgh Land Bank will cover all necessary costs and expenses related to acquiring the property

• The transfer comes at no cost to the city

• Council gave the resolution an affirmative recommendation with no discussion during the meeting
labels_to_summaries.G29:
- A City Council committee approved a resolution to transfer a city-owned property to the Pittsburgh Land Bank.
- The property is located at 219 Reifert Street in the 30th Ward, also known as Block 33-K, Lot 128.
- The Land Bank will pay the city $1.00 plus any expenses related to the acquisition.
- The committee passed the resolution with an "affirmative recommendation" without any discussion, moving it forward for a final vote.
labels_to_summaries.O29:
- The City Council approved Resolution 2025-1727 allowing the Pittsburgh Land Bank to acquire the city-owned property at 219 Reifert Street (Block 33-K, Lot 128) in the 30th Ward, Council District 3.  
- The acquisition will cost the Land Bank $1.00 plus any necessary incidental expenses, with no cost to the City.  
- The resolution authorizes the Land Bank to take full ownership rights and manage the property as needed.  
- The motion to approve was seconded and passed unanimously with an affirmative recommendation.
